section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Read Section 6.3 of Applied Discrete Structures. You will read about four properties that are satisfied by certain relations. Two combinations of these properties, when true, characterize relations that are particularly important. They are partial orderings and equivalence relations. Make an effort to memorize the terms in this section - they will appear throughout the rest of the book.

statement.p: Recall that in geometry, two triangles are similar if and only if their corresponding angles have the same measure. What kind of relation is this on the set of all triangles on the plane?

section.p: Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:

statement.p: Prove that congruence modulo m is a transitive relation on the set of integers. Do this by assuming that a \equiv_m b and b\equiv_m c, and applying the definition for \equiv_m to conclude that a \equiv_m c.
Draw the ordering diagram for the relation divides on the divisors of 40=2^3 \cdot 5.

Let A = \{a, b, c, d\}. Draw the graphs of relations on A where:
The first relation is reflexive, symmetric, but not transitive.
The second relation is transitive, but not symmetric and not reflexive.
The third relation is both an equivalence relation and a partial ordering.

Let A = \{0, 1, 2, 3\} and let r = \{(0, 0), (1, 1), (2, 2), (3, 3), (1, 2), (2, 1), (3, 0), (0, 3)\}
Verify that r is an equivalence relation on A.
Let a \in A and define c(a) = \{b \in A \mid a rb\}. c(a)the equivalence class of a under r c(a) is called the equivalence class of a under rEquivalence Class. Find c(a) for each element a \in A.
Show that \{c(a) \mid a \in A\} forms a partition of A for this set A.
Let r be an equivalence relation on an arbitrary set A. Prove that the set of all equivalence classes under r constitutes a partition of A.
Describe the equivalence classes under the relation congruence modulo 10 on the integers.

Let A be the set of strings of 0's and 1's of length 3 or less; and let B be the set of strings of 0's and 1's of length 3. What properties do the following relations have?
Define the relation of w on A by x w y if x has the same number of 1's as y. For example, 01 w 100, but 01 w 101 is false.
Define the the relation d on B defined by x d y if x differs from y in exactly one position. For example, 100 d 101, but 100 d 111 is false.
Define the the relation c defined on A by x c y if x is contained within y. For example, 10 c 101, but 11 c 101 is false.
For any of these relations that are partial orderings, draw the Hasse diagram for that relation. For any of them that is an equivalence relation, identify the equivalence classes.

section.title: Congruence Modulo n
section.p: This is a fundamental relation on the set of integers.

notation.description: a is congruent to b modulo m
a is congruent to b modulo m

statement.p: Let m be a positive integer, m\geq 2. We define congruence modulo m to be the relation \equiv_m defined on the integers by a \equiv_m b \Leftrightarrow m \mid (a-b)
